articles.headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Libya in Wake of Crackdown
articles.snippet: The U.S. moved to increase diplomatic pressure on Libya, suspending relations and imposing unilateral sanctions.
articles.abstract: The U.S. moved to increase diplomatic pressure on Libya, suspending relations and imposing unilateral sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States closed its embassy in Tripoli on Friday and imposed unilateral sanctions against Libya, including the freezing of billions in government assets, as the Obama administration made its most aggressive move against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi since his security forces opened fire on protesters.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Consumers Hold On to Products Longer
articles.snippet: For some Americans the recession has left something behind: a greater interest in making stuff last.
articles.abstract: For some Americans the recession has left something behind: a greater interest in making stuff last.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throw away the cellphone after two years? Not so fast. Ditch the flat-panel TV for an even thinner model? Maybe next year. Replace the blouse with the hole? Darn it!

articles.headline: Tax Breaks to Take Before They Go
articles.snippet: When governments make promises they can’t pay for, something has to give. That something can be tax breaks.
articles.abstract: When governments make promises they can’t pay for, something has to give. That something can be tax breaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Part of what lies at the heart of the heated debate in state capitals and Washington over the last couple of weeks is a legitimate concern about a pretty simple question: have governments made too many promises about what they should provide without collecting enough money to fulfill them all?

articles.headline: Graying Audience Returns to Movies
articles.snippet: An older audience has made a reassertion of its multiplex power, giving Hollywood a glimpse of its graying future.
articles.abstract: An older audience has made a reassertion of its multiplex power, giving Hollywood a glimpse of its graying future.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood and older Americans have never had much use for each other. The 50-plus crowd doesn’t go to opening weekends or buy popcorn; a youth-obsessed Hollywood has happily ignored them.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Biggest Fish Face Little Risk of Being Caught
articles.snippet: You’re entitled to wonder whether any executives who helped kindle the financial crisis will see jail time.
articles.abstract: You’re entitled to wonder whether any executives who helped kindle the financial crisis will see jail time.
articles.lead_paragraph: So much for Angelo Mozilo taking the fall for the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Seeking to Weed Out Drivel, Google Adjusts Search Engine
articles.snippet: Google’s change is a tacit acknowledgment that an industry devoted to gaming search results had increasingly managed to pollute the search engine by pushing less relevant sites higher.
articles.abstract: Google’s change is a tacit acknowledgment that an industry devoted to gaming search results had increasingly managed to pollute the search engine by pushing less relevant sites higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a tacit admission that Web publishers are flooding its search engine with low-quality pages, Google has revised its methods to improve the usefulness of its results.

articles.headline: Sheen Tantrum Likely to Cost in the Millions
articles.snippet: Halting production of “Two and a Half Men” after Charlie Sheen’s antics may cost CBS and Warner Brothers $250 million.
articles.abstract: Halting production of “Two and a Half Men” after Charlie Sheen’s antics may cost CBS and Warner Brothers $250 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charlie Sheen’s latest antics may leave CBS and Warner Brothers with a quarter-billion-dollar headache.

articles.headline: In Libya Capital, Long Bread Lines and Barricades
articles.snippet: An effort by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was in control appeared to backfire as foreign journalists he invited in discovered open defiance.
articles.abstract: An effort by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was in control appeared to backfire as foreign journalists he invited in discovered open defiance.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya  A bold play by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was firmly in control of Libya appeared to backfire Saturday, as foreign journalists he invited to the capital discovered blocks of the city in open defiance of his authority.

articles.headline: Waiting Seven Years for Two Answers
articles.snippet: In a seemingly endless mortgage case, statements from bank employees contradicted one another, and three institutions claimed to hold the title to the house.
articles.abstract: In a seemingly endless mortgage case, statements from bank employees contradicted one another, and three institutions claimed to hold the title to the house.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Zella Mae Green of Georgia filed for bankruptcy to save her home from foreclosure in 2004, she and her lawyer wanted to know two things: Did she actually owe any back payments on her mortgage? And, if so, to whom?

articles.headline: A Corporate Sleuth Tries the Credit Rating Field
articles.snippet: Jules Kroll, known for corporate detective work, wants to shake up a business tarnished by the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Jules Kroll, known for corporate detective work, wants to shake up a business tarnished by the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FEW people ever penetrate the dark side of money, but Jules Kroll is one of them.

articles.headline: A Patrol for the Web’s Playgrounds
articles.snippet: A company’s nationwide network of moderators aims to keep Web sites free of cyberbullies.
articles.abstract: A company’s nationwide network of moderators aims to keep Web sites free of cyberbullies.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE dinosaurs didn’t know it, but their world might have narrowly averted upheaval this month.

articles.headline: In Indiana, Clues to Future of Wisconsin Labor
articles.snippet: The experience of Indiana, where the governor ended bargaining for state employees, shows how much is at stake for workers and the government.
articles.abstract: The experience of Indiana, where the governor ended bargaining for state employees, shows how much is at stake for workers and the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and other officials who are pushing to eliminate or weaken collective bargaining by government employees say their goal is to save millions of dollars and increase government’s flexibility to run its operations.

articles.headline: Regulation Lax as Gas Wells’ Tainted Water Hits Rivers
articles.snippet: A method to extract more natural gas often produces wastewater laced with toxic substances.
articles.abstract: A method to extract more natural gas often produces wastewater laced with toxic substances.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American landscape is dotted with hundreds of thousands of new wells and drilling rigs, as the country scrambles to tap into this century’s gold rush — for natural gas.

articles.headline: On the Stump, Gingrich Puts Focus on Faith
articles.snippet: As a presidential candidate, Newt Gingrich would offer political acumen but would also have to grapple with aspects of his life and career that could give pause to elements of the electorate.
articles.abstract: As a presidential candidate, Newt Gingrich would offer political acumen but would also have to grapple with aspects of his life and career that could give pause to elements of the electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Newt Gingrich needs no introduction to most Republican audiences. It is the reintroduction that is the challenge.

articles.headline: The Vacuum After Qaddafi
articles.snippet: Because Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent the last 40 years hollowing out every single institution that might challenge his authority, there are few options to succeed him.
articles.abstract: Because Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent the last 40 years hollowing out every single institution that might challenge his authority, there are few options to succeed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi sounded a resonant warning, exhorting his dwindling supporters toward civil war.

articles.headline: Rebels in Libya Gain Power and Defectors
articles.snippet: Rebels challenging Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed their firepower and military coordination as defecting officers in the east took steps to establish a unified command.
articles.abstract: Rebels challenging Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed their firepower and military coordination as defecting officers in the east took steps to establish a unified command.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAWIYAH, Libya  The Libyan rebels challenging Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi demonstrated their increasing military coordination and firepower on Sunday, as defecting officers in the east took steps to establish a unified command while their followers in this rebel-held city, just outside the leader’s stronghold in the capital, displayed tanks, Kalashnikovs and antiaircraft guns.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Publishers Look Beyond Bookstores
articles.snippet: As the big bookstores change course, publishers are pushing into new stores, like Michaels and Lowe’s, hoping to catch shoppers’ eyes.
articles.abstract: As the big bookstores change course, publishers are pushing into new stores, like Michaels and Lowe’s, hoping to catch shoppers’ eyes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kitson, a group of boutiques based in Los Angeles, is the kind of store that appears regularly in the tabloids for both its stylish clothes and its celebrity clientele like Sean Combs and Joe Jonas.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Tremors from Libya Contribute to Oil Price Cycles
articles.snippet: A spike in the price of oil has many wondering how high it will go and what the fallout could be to recovery in the United States.
articles.abstract: A spike in the price of oil has many wondering how high it will go and what the fallout could be to recovery in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is no oil shock  not yet, anyway.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Cutting Out Middleman to Sell Small Ads Online
articles.snippet: Online publishers like CBS and Forbes are selling the tiny ads on their Web sites, rather than letting a third-party network promote teeth whitening and herbal remedies.
articles.abstract: Online publishers like CBS and Forbes are selling the tiny ads on their Web sites, rather than letting a third-party network promote teeth whitening and herbal remedies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Online publishers, who have long been dismayed with the revenue from some of their advertising, are increasingly taking matters into their own hands.

articles.headline: Insulting Chuck Lorre, Not Abuse, Gets Sheen Sidelined
articles.snippet: Allegations of violence against women failed to get Charlie Sheen off the air, but insulting his boss has.
articles.abstract: Allegations of violence against women failed to get Charlie Sheen off the air, but insulting his boss has.
articles.lead_paragraph: As more and more women have come into the work force, corporate America has made significant, if agonizingly slow, progress in making sure its attitudes and the conduct of its leadership reflect those changes. It’s no longer a “Mad Men” world where women are expected to fetch coffee and whiskey and service their bosses in other ways.

articles.headline: Behind a Rise in Auto Sales, Easier Credit
articles.snippet: After scaling back auto lending, banks and automakers’ lending arms have started to issue loans more aggressively.
articles.abstract: After scaling back auto lending, banks and automakers’ lending arms have started to issue loans more aggressively.
articles.lead_paragraph: Detroit is crowing that the auto industry is back, but so far, at least, it is a success story built as much on a revival in lending as on the development of desirable cars.

articles.headline: White House Sweats, and He’s the Cause
articles.snippet: President Obama’s personal trainer, Cornell McClellan, has also been working with many top staff members.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s personal trainer, Cornell McClellan, has also been working with many top staff members.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Michael Strautmanis had no sooner started his White House job as a deputy assistant to the president when his boss began badgering him.

articles.headline: As Regimes Fall in Arab World, Al Qaeda Sees History Fly By
articles.snippet: The powerful protests spreading across the Middle East and North Africa have shunned the two central tenets of Al Qaeda’s credo: murderous violence and religious fanaticism.
articles.abstract: The powerful protests spreading across the Middle East and North Africa have shunned the two central tenets of Al Qaeda’s credo: murderous violence and religious fanaticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, the leaders of Al Qaeda have denounced the Arab world’s dictators as heretics and puppets of the West and called for their downfall. Now, people in country after country have risen to topple their leaders  and Al Qaeda has played absolutely no role.

articles.headline: Unions Debate What to Give to Save Bargaining
articles.snippet: Republican lawmakers have won concessions by fighting what labor sees as a basic right.
articles.abstract: Republican lawmakers have won concessions by fighting what labor sees as a basic right.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Wisconsin’s governor and public employees square off in the biggest public sector labor showdown since Ronald Reagan fired striking air traffic controllers in 1981, government employees’ unions in a range of states are weighing whether to give ground on wages, benefits and work rules to preserve basic bargaining rights.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: Tribeca and Sundance Festivals Plan Big Growth
articles.snippet: Using on-demand technology and Web services, the Tribeca and Sundance film festivals are aiming to gain a wider audience for independent movies.
articles.abstract: Using on-demand technology and Web services, the Tribeca and Sundance film festivals are aiming to gain a wider audience for independent movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two big film festival operators, Tribeca Enterprises and the Sundance Institute, are about to greatly expand their efforts to use technology to bring specialty movies to a national audience.

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Forces Hit Back at Rebels
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces struck back at his opponents with special forces, regular army troops and, rebels said, fighter jets, in an escalation of hostilities that brought Libya a step closer to civil war.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces struck back at his opponents with special forces, regular army troops and, rebels said, fighter jets, in an escalation of hostilities that brought Libya a step closer to civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces struck back at his opponents on three fronts on Monday, with special forces, regular army troops and, rebels said, fighter jets, in an escalation of hostilities that brought Libya a step closer to civil war.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Obama Backs Easing State Health Law Mandates
articles.snippet: The president told governors he backed letting states opt out of parts of the plan earlier than is currently allowed.
articles.abstract: The president told governors he backed letting states opt out of parts of the plan earlier than is currently allowed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who has stood by his landmark health care law through court attacks and legislative efforts to repeal it, told the nation’s governors on Monday that he was willing to amend the measure to give states the ability to opt out of its most controversial requirements right from the start, including the mandate that most people buy insurance.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Kevin Sack
